reviewTitle: It is an excellent PC to start streaming and more
reviewedIn: Reviewed in the United States on February 11, 2023
reviewDescription: Let me just start off by saying that I don't know much about PCs, and I was worried about taking the leap to purchase one, even after doing a couple weeks of research AND asking my hardcore PC gamer friends for advice. However, I am super impressed and so thankful that I chose this one! It is sooo worth the money! I started getting into PC gaming not too long ago, mainly playing Minecraft, and much more recently, Valorant. Both games ran like garbage on my old laptop, so I decided to upgrade - and let me tell you that this PC has not missed a BEAT! The only issues I've ever had with Valorant on this PC were due to internal issues with the game itself, not the PC. No lag AT ALL - same goes for Minecraft and a few smaller games I've played. Everything runs absolutely great! I will say I was a little worried when I opened the box up (I was hoping it hadn't gotten damaged during shipping), but it was actually packaged really nicely and came with a nice quick start guide, which was really useful for me, considering I've never set up a gaming PC before. Everything was hooked up properly internally, so it was plug and play after getting everything arranged the way I wanted on my desk, and I instantly loved the RGB lights! They're awesome! You can change the colors just by pressing a button on the top of the PC. I leave mine on the solid rainbow setting most of the time, but there are so many colors you can rotate through! The other nice thing is that it has a lot of open space inside, so I could definitely upgrade it as needed, and there's 5 cooling fans! It never gets hot (even after HOURS of playing Valorant) and is pretty quiet. The mouse and keyboard included are okay - I'm sure most pro gamers will want to upgrade, but for now, they work good for me. Coupled with my new 24" Sceptre Edgeless Curved monitor, it's a perfect match for me. If I ever need to purchase another PC in the future, I'd definitely buy one again

reviewedIn: Reviewed in the United States on April 2, 2023
reviewDescription: I don't mind noise, it's pretty quiet. The rgb lights are cool. As a fresh pc from someone who came from an outdated laptop, it's great. I have added a few things. I've added 32gb of ram, and a wd blue 1 tb m.2 card. I've also added a new wifi card to the PCIe slot. As it's pretty damn slow.  I pay for 1 gb of internet speed and definitely needed the new card as it only gets up to 200mb But other than that it's great. If you plan on putting a heavy processor you'll likely need a new motherboard. But for what it is, so far it's great, no issues.

reviewedIn: Reviewed in the United States on April 12, 2023
reviewDescription: I have the Ryzen 5 3600 with the rtx 3050 versionIt can run:Apex at 89-105 fps at max settingsMW2 at 70-90 fps at recommended settingsFar cry 6 at 65-80 fps at medium to high settingsThose are the games I‚Äôve played and tested so far. reviewDescription: I got this computer thinking it would only be the computer but I also recieved a keyboard and mouse! They seem to work pretty well for my mom. reviewDescription: At $1200 used, it was hard to tell as there was barely a speck of dust. All parts in total would have been $1600+. reviewTitle: Amazed at the performance for the size & cost
reviewedIn: Reviewed in the United States on April 8, 2023
reviewDescription: I had never considered a mini-pc before. I had always assumed they were little more than toys.  A few weeks ago I read a very positive review from one of the PC World editors about the Beelink SER5 with a Ryzen 5,16G DDR4, a 512 GB SSD, Wifi 6.0, Bluetooth 5 and Windows 11 Pro.  I had a 5 year old Desktop that will not upgrade to Windows 11, so I decided to risk the purchase, which was just under $300 at that time, plus tax. and free Amazon shipping.I am not a gamer, so I didn't need gaming specs.  However, I do a lot of Zoom meetings, run two 27 inch monitors, and use data base programs. I also do Family History research, edit a lot of photographs, but not much video, use the latest version of MS Office and do a lot of high resolution scanning.  I'm just trying to make the point that, while I'm not a Power User, I do a lot more than email and browsing the internet.I spent 4-6 hours configuring, loading programs and transferring data, and haven't looked back since.  I am amazed at the power of this unit for my workload, and it is also very quiet. I was expecting to spend between $800 - $1200 to replace my desktop, and since I already had monitors and wireless keyboard/mouse combo, my total outlay was only $300 plus tax for a unit that completely meets my needs.I have not done any research on reliability and I have not needed tech support, so I cannot speak to either of those, but for the cost/performance of this unit, I'll take my chances.  So far, I am more than satisfied with the purchase.

reviewedIn: Reviewed in the United States on April 10, 2023
reviewDescription: It came with everything required, including spare cables and a vesa mount.I haven't had the reboot issue others have mentioned, but i wiped it and installed Fedora server. Every time i reboot it remotely, it comes back up again within a minute or so.I installed an extra SSD which was dead simple, and has extra cables and screws.It's currently running over 20 docker containers and barely breaking a sweat. Zero issues with temperature. I haven't tried throwing something more resource hungry at it, like zoneminder for video.It's running the entire house, doing what i wanted it to do, with room to grow. No complaints.

reviewedIn: Reviewed in the United States on March 10, 2023
reviewDescription: This is the first mini-PC I have purchased and I was extremely apprehensive.  Two things concerned me before making the purchased.  Speed and heat, within the first two or three days both of those concerns were put to rest.  I have not one complaint about the product and quite surprised it performs as good as it does.  Restarts take around 9 seconds and I have not seen any decrease in performance.I use the unit in a headless scenario and remote desktop is used to access the system.  The Wake On-LAN feature is great and this means I can be placed out of the way.  This unit serves its purpose of a machine I can do schoolwork. I am very happy with the Bee-Link brand and should I decide to purchase another mini-PC in the future, it will definitely be a Bee-Link.

reviewTitle: Fast but have to unplug it too often
reviewedIn: Reviewed in the United States on January 16, 2023
reviewDescription: I bought this little box to replace a large HP desktop.  The good:  it is very fast and compact.  The bad:  every time I've done updates that require a restart, I have to unplug it and plug it back in.  Every second time I start it up, I have to unplug it and plug it back in.  I contacted tech support, but they gave me some generic suggestions such as replace the hdmi cable or get a new power supply. I have cleared CMOS using the pinhole and that fixes the problem for one or 2 reboots.  They have also suggested replacing or cleaning the connectors for the RAM and SSD drive I added, but I am reluctant to do that.  I now have it connected to a switchable power strip.  Instead of physically removing the plug, I just switch off the power strip, count to 10, and turn it back on.  That has always worked so far.  It's a nice little box, but the power issue, although irksome, is not a show stopper.

reviewedIn: Reviewed in the United States on March 20, 2023
reviewDescription: Received mine in 2 days when shipping showed 5 days.  It was packaged well.  The sticker on outside of the case shows M800 SFF, but mine came with an i7-6700, 2x16GB DDR4 (4 slots total), 1TB SSD (not M.2), 2 - 4K DP++ ports, 1 VGA port, a serial port and SATA DVD-RW internal.  It has new keyboard & optical mouse (cheap ones - but not bad) and the WiFi/Bluetooth adapter is a USB 2.0 dongle (802.11n - 150Mbps).  It came with a digitally registered copy of W10 Pro as well as a power cord. It was very clean inside & the only issue I've had is the WiFi/BT dongle disappears occasionally & must be reset in W10P.  3 empty card slots below:* PCI Express x1 card slot* PCI Express card slot (physical link width x16; negotiable link width x4, x1)* PCI Express x16 graphics card slotI've bought a few PCs from SJComputers in the past & every one was as advertised and had no issues.

reviewDescription: I grabbed this for a stand alone server to host my Plex DVR from an antenna and tuner in the house. reviewedIn: Reviewed in the United States on April 23, 2023
reviewDescription: The computer is fine but not as listed. There is no DVD drive (like what's in the picture for the listing), the "wifi" is a usb add on (not built in and old slow usb 2.0 version), the bluetooth is a usb dongle (not built in and old slow 4.0 version). Everything else is as described and for less than $300 minus $100 from a gift card, I am happy with it. I purchased a nice quality usb 3.0 wifi adapter that works much better (about 4 times faster than the included cheapo adapter).I just really don't like descriptions with half truths. I would still have bought it if they had been honest about the wifi and bluetooth being add-on adapters rather than trying to be sneaky about it. I would have given a 5 star rating based on the price and what I got for it had they been honest.

reviewedIn: Reviewed in the United States on April 7, 2023
reviewDescription: When the computer first arrived, early March, I unpacked it, and I was very impressed with the care taken in packing it for shipping.  It appeared, from the packing, that the computer was brand new.  I removed all of the components and hooked it up for use.  In hooking up the computer, I discovered that one of the cords necessary for completing the hookup was missing.  So, I had to go out and get a cord to complete the hookup of the monitors.  Two monitors were included, however, only one cord was included.  Initially, the computer performed perfectly.  No issues with speed or operation.  However, since that time, the computer seems to crash at least once a month.  I receive an error message, and a message that something has gone wrong, and that the computer will have to shut off and restart.  As I was completing this review, it occurred to me again.  I purchased the warranty for the computer, so I do have some peace of mind.  However, it is disappointing to know that at any time the computer will crash and have to restart, just as I am in the middle of an important project.  I won't make a buy or don't buy recommendation, just wanted to make an honest and accurate review of the product.

reviewDescription: This little guy is a monster. Obviously, you will not be able to play new AAA games on high settings. It is a mini PC. That being said, it runs SOME newer games on lower settings. I have run Diablo II Resurrected, Destiny 2, and Elden Ring (low graphics settings) seamlessly. For other daily computing tasks this thing runs multiple applications like a hot blade through butter. One thing I would like to point out is that some manufacturers of the AMR5 load RGB files on the OS before you receive it. This company did not do that. I powered up and had to set up Windows 11. This is a good thing because otherwise I would have had to do a factory reset for safety. If you understand the drawbacks to not having a dedicated GPU, I believe this is a GREAT buy.

reviewTitle: I am really loving this Mini Pc
reviewedIn: Reviewed in the United States üá∫üá∏ on February 26, 2023
reviewDescription: I am not a review writer, and I am a computer nerd who never believed in these Mini Computers, I have always had custom computers made for me by Dell / Alienware. I read reviews on this mini pc and did research online and was pleased with the hardware in the mini pc. I wanted the space also for my computer room, with 5 monitors and two full-size desktops units, this is what I needed. It was delivered fast and booted up really fast. The mini pc runs so quietly that I have to look to see if it's really on, and the speed is great and I have been able to play about any game I want with no problem. I am already looking for my future Mini Pc to replace my current Alien Laptop when it bites the dust. So I highly recommend the mini pc, but again always look at the hardware and spec to make sure you are getting the most for what you paying. But the cost of these units compared to the full-size desktop or laptop, are not even close and if you watch the spec you will get a unit just as good as the full-size units and in some areas much better performance in a smaller package. I am trying to find out where I can purchase the upgrades for the pc?

reviewTitle: Good for what it is. Definitely has limitations.
reviewedIn: Reviewed in the United States on February 11, 2023
reviewDescription: Overall I am happy with this purchase. I was in the market for a mini PC to use as an emulator box for early to mid 2000's games. Most PS2 games are stable at 1080P, some can be scaled up to 2-4k but performance is inconsistent and I don't want to adjust settings for every game, so I'll keep it at 1080P. Likewise GameCube runs stable at 1440. No issues so far emulating PSP PSX and N64 in 4K. I paired this with a 12TB external HD for game storage and the setup is working out great so far. I haven't tried any modern games on this and I don't plan on doing so either, I'm sure it could handle them but I would rather play older games that look great on modern hardware than modern games on garbage settings.This is not a knock against the hardware because this little PC is solid and is pretty much exactly what I was looking for, I'm just not a fan of Windows 11 that comes preinstalled. It doesn't seem to be as flexible as previous versions of Windows. I may install windows 10 on it in the future if it continues to bother me but that's getting nit picky. Overall this is a solid little machine that's great for playing games that are 10 or more years old. Any newer games played on this type of hardware without a dedicated GPU is going to be a mixed bag.

reviewedIn: Reviewed in the United States on January 24, 2023
reviewDescription: I've been using this as a HTPC to consume media and for Steam Link. I'm pretty happy with it. It's pretty small, and has the form factor of a thick chapter book.Performance:Performance is pretty snappy. I have it as my HTPC on my 4k TV. It's able to play videos and stream content pretty well. I'm running it off Wi-Fi, and I didn't notice any hiccups. The only gaming I've done with it so far has been with Steam Link. I played a few games with it. Mostly Tabletop Simulator and Civilization. I get 100Mbps with it, and haven't noticed any disruptions. For the more heavy games, I have a separate computer for that purpose.Internal Components:I opened the little MiniPC to see what the inside looked like. I did notice that there's an additional slot for another M.2 drive. The PC comes with 2x8 DDR4 RAM sticks clocked at 2400MHz.Sound and Lights:This is probably my biggest complaint. The lights on here are pretty bright. They alternate RGB colors, and I can't turn them off. The lights don't cover any air intake, so I just put electrical tape over it to mute the device.I have it set to AUTO mode. The sound coming from the exhaust is like a PS4. If I just web browsing, then it's pretty quiet. It does get nosier when I have multiple apps running.Overall:I'm happy with the device so far. It's more powerful than other MiniPCs I've looked at within this price range, and it's worked well as a HTPC.

reviewedIn: Reviewed in the United States on April 15, 2023
reviewDescription: The Dell optiolex machines themselves are great. This review is more about buying from sellers on Amazon. This will be the last time I buy a computer on Amazon, unless it's sold by the manufacturer.The Machine I received was modified by seller from original dell configuration. This has happened on multiple occasions. If you have a hardware failure and contact the manufacturer you will have an issue.  I.e. When your hard drive goes bad they will replace it, and then expect you to send back the old drive. However you don't have the old drive because it was swapped with some other piece of hardware.  So now you are paying dell a penalty for not sending the drive back, or you are buying a new drive instead of having it covered under warranty.Also the image on the machine was not an OEM dell OS image.  Who knows if sellers are installing malware on these systems.I needed this machine for a customers emergency, and my usual authorized reseller was out of stock so I had no other choice but to use it.  Lesson learned.

reviewedIn: Reviewed in the United States üá∫üá∏ on September 28, 2022
reviewDescription: Preface with that I work in IT several years of which was onsite desktop support. Was looking for a prebuilt as I just don't want to take time actually researching each piece of hardware and spending my time outside of work doing more work stuff. So a slight increase in cost overall is well worth the convenience. The PC works almost as expected but with some things that just don't make sense for a $700 PC. The glass cover is held down by magnets. If the pull tab that's attached comes off there's no real easy way to the case without something to pop it open with and something about popping open a glass door with a screwdriver doesn't seem like a good idea. Also, it appears that there is supposed to be a magnet both top and bottom of said glass door and one is missing. Only mildly discomforting thinking there's possibly a free-range magnet hanging out somewhere inside a PC where it's not meant to be. One of the top USB ports doesn't work, no power and I haven't bothered to see if there's anyway remedy this but on a brand new PC it shouldn't happen. Peripherals connected to other ports work as expected but not on this one. Not a huge deal with putting the non-power intensive devices on a USB hub which most would have to purchase separately. Purchased this PC aware of some specs and with the understanding that if I did indeed plan to game at all I would likely need at least some sort of video card/GPU upgrade. That being said it was either a 2060 or a 1660 and after reading some comments I went with the 1660 as I didn't want to take chances on needing to upgrade a power supply just yet as well. Now installing graphics cards in the past has always gone one of two ways for any HP, Dell or IBM machine I've done. There's either a tab to pop a latch up to remove the rear device faceplates or individual plates held in place with screws. You then remove the faceplate, insert the new card and either screw the card into place with aforementioned screw or press the latch back into place to secure your new card. Not the situation here, this PC has fully molded faceplates pressed into the casing. They are thin, sharp metal tabs that are lightly perforated so a fair amount of pressure is required to pop them out while you hope not to damage and circuitry below. I installed the card but it would leave anyone with it hanging only by the adapter connection. I had to "borrow" a screw from the back of the case otherwise used for the power supply and repurposed it to hold the new card in place. I called the technical support number on the provided contact card that states to call before returning to give them a chance at resolving it. I left a voicemail with my name, the issue and my number Friday afternoon and have yet to hear back now Wednesday evening. Their answering service states hours are M-F 9-5 EST so if you happen to work those same, very common, hours you're apparently on your own or need to take some time off to try and get support for the $700 computer you just purchased. So that leaves me here fighting between wiping the drive, sending it back for a refund and starting from scratch or dealing with the shortcomings that I've found so far and may find more of down the line. Gave it three stars because outside all of that, I did receive a relatively functioning PC.

reviewTitle: A good All-in-one PC, hardware upgrades are difficult though
reviewedIn: Reviewed in the United States üá∫üá∏ on September 11, 2022
reviewDescription: I was excited to receive this for review, I haven't used an all-in-one form factor (other than an iMac) in a really long time, and I was interested to see what someone would get for around $700. Ultimately, this is using laptop internals, packed inside of a computer monitor. The power adapter only has an output of 65 watts, a normal desktop processor alone draws at least that much power and sometimes double. Computers have become powerful enough so that most people don't really need full-fledged desktops like that anymore though. A neat and tidy setup like this is more practical and elegant, so long as you don't need anything too powerful.The first thing I noticed was the quality of the screen, it's as good (if not better) than the average $200 monitor in terms of vibrance and brightness and significantly better than a $700 laptop screen. It's 24 inches in size, with a 1080p resolution, but I think that's enough for general purposes. The speakers are about like what you would get on a TV or monitor at this size, I wouldn't call them 'tinny" like you might for a cheap tablet or laptop, but they aren't gonna overwhelm you either. They are fine and sound good enough, most people will be happy with the sound quality.One big plus is that this comes with a wireless mouse and keyboard. I think it totally destroys the aesthetic of an all-in-one when you have unnecessary cables hanging off the back of the computer. The keyboard is a low-profile membrane style, it's decent but not great (keep in mind that I use mechanical keyboards, so I have higher than average standards). I think the mouse is a little better than the keyboard.The internals of the computer are really modern, you get a 12th gen Core i3 with 8GB of DDR4 3200MHz and 512GB of fast, NVMe storage. The processor has 2x performance cores with hyperthreading and 4x efficiency cores, giving you a total of 6 cores/eight threads. With a lot of these twelfth generation CPUs, I don't think the e-cores really does anything except make it look good on paper, but with the Core i3, it does actually help lift up the performance a bit more than if it was just a dual core. To make things simple, the CPU is fast and so is the NVMe drive. Everything was really snappy and fluid and responsive while I was testing this computer for a couple weeks and using it as my primary computer.One downside to this design is that it's not very easy to make small upgrades like adding more RAM, another 8GB of it would really help out (if not now, then in a couple of years down the road). It is physically possible to do, but it's harder than adding RAM to a laptop and I don't think I recommend doing it. I may end up doing later and if my opinion changes, then I will update this review.Pros+Bright, vibrant 24-inch screen looks greatModern internals with 12th generation Intel Core i3, good wireless card, and fast SSDGood port selection with five USB ports (1x USB C with 10Gbps, 1x USB A with 10Gbps and 2x with 5Gbps)Wifi 6 and Bluetooth 5Windows 11 (although this could be a negative too, some people hate Windows 11 but I think it's better)Wireless mouse and keyboard includedCons-Keyboard feels a little mushy to type on, it's membrane (I think so)Hard to upgrade hardware components, it's difficult to remove the back panel to get to the internal components

reviewTitle: To NUC or not to NUC, that is the question (see details).  Conditionally Recommended
reviewedIn: Reviewed in the United States üá∫üá∏ on August 16, 2022
reviewDescription: I have mixed feelings on the Acer Aspire C24-1700-UA91 AIO Desktop.On the one hand, the Aspire C24-1700-UA91 is a really good general-use computer.  The IPS panel is well-lit, has great color, and has great viewing angles.  The Core i3-1215U, though toward the bottom of the Core-branded CPUs in the 12th gen, is actually just as fast as an i7-2600 (same 4c/8t configuration).  8GB should be considered the minimum RAM for actually DOING anything.  Fortunately, Win11 doesn't really appear to be any more memory-intensive than Win10, and 8GB is enough for running Office 365, or a bunch of browser tabs.  Other Aspire C24s have allowed you to replace the DIMM, but you'll want to check if you're interested.  The NVMe SSD isn't slow, but it doesn't perform up to the level of a fast Gen3 x4 SSD, either.  Built-in wifi is fine, with 802.11ax (2.4/5-only, no 6Ghz), and average performance internal antennas.  The computer manages smooth, full-screen 1080p, which plenty of SFFs struggle with.  The Aspire also has above-average speakers, making this a good dorm-room PC for school during the day, and streaming video at night.Considering that this is essentially just a monitor with a laptop motherboard integrated, it's no wonder that the packaging is excellent.  For just the footprint of a 24" monitor, you get a full computer.  The included keyboard and mouse continue the theme of maximum space economy, with the keyboard able to stow away on the computer's stand.  The mouse is a compact unit, too.  Speaking of the peripherals, I put the included AAA batteries in the keyboard (2x) and mouse (1x).  Upon noticing that the PC didn't recognize peripherals, I realized that I had to put the USB dongle (in the battery compartment of the mouse) in one of the PC's USB-A ports.  This is annoying because: 1.) the PC only has 5 USB ports, 2.) it's pretty normal to have Bluetooth peripherals, and 3.) this PC HAS Bluetooth!My misgivings about the Acer have to do with some of my prior experiences with all-in-ones.  Generally, they haven't performed all that well, and they tend to be less reliable and expandable than regular PCs.  Though the Acer alleviates my concerns about performance (and to an extent, expandability), high levels of integration do tend to impact longevity.  However, with relatively leisurely workloads, this PC will probably last 5-10 years.  When pushed, the fan in the thermal solution can be heard, but it's never overly loud.So, I LIKE the Acer, but I also got it for a very specific use case.  The Aspire is a reception desk computer at a salon, where it's used for accounting, inventory, appointment management, and payment processing tasks. The tiny footprint is even smaller than if I'd taken a bare monitor and mounted an inexpensive NUC to the back, and is perfect as a point-of-sale computer.  At $650, you can go the monitor + NUC + Bluetooth peripheral route and save a little money, but it won't be anywhere near as neat (a single power cable beats multiple power cables, plus an HDMI cable to manage).  Conditionally Recommended

reviewTitle: Solid All-In-One PC For Basic Needs
reviewedIn: Reviewed in the United States üá∫üá∏ on August 10, 2022
reviewDescription: I've had a couple Acer laptops in the past that I really liked and were long lasting and I wanted a PC for the bedroom, so when this popped up on Vine I jumped on it. I've never owned a desktop all-in-one unit before, either separate components or laptops so this is a little fresh for me.It came well packed and the stand is easily attached to the screen (no tools required) and it has a little wire management bracket you can slip on. It would have been nice if you had the option to adjust the height, but you can't as far as I can tell. The build quality seems great, no issues there. It comes with Windows 11 which is also new for me as I'm still on Windows 10 with my other PC. The included accessories (keyboard, mouse) are actually decent. They're wireless which is what I prefer.Screen quality is good, with solid color/uniformity. It's a standard 24" 1080p matte 60Hz IPS panel. No high refresh or HDR or anything like that and it doesn't get super bright if that is what you need. About what you would expect in this price range and a good fit for the specs it has. Operation is fast with the 512 NVMe SSD and 12th gen mobile Intel i3 processor. No GPU is included. Only 8 GBs of RAM which is decent for this price but 16GB is starting to become the standard nowadays. I haven't tried cracking it open yet to see if the RAM can be upgraded and I assume there is no space for an extra storage drive. This unit can't handle any modern games with only Intel graphics or do any serious productivity work so keep that in mind when buying. All the ports work and it has the latest Wi-Fi and Bluetooth standards which is a big plus (both perform well). The included speakers aren't very good as you would expect (same with the mic and webcam), I use headphones. There is constant fan noise which can get obnoxious if there is a heavy load. AiO units use laptop hardware from what I've seen so it likely has a cheap laptop fan for cooling and performs as such.Overall I would say this is a solid unit for anyone looking for an All-In-One setup that wants something more substantial than a laptop as far as screen size and connectivity go, even with the minor faults it has. Recommended.

reviewTitle: Beautiful display, fast CPU for an AIO, and just all around great performance for the price
reviewedIn: Reviewed in the United States üá∫üá∏ on October 25, 2022
reviewDescription: I really have no complaints for this Acer Aspire AIO. In all fairness, this is my first time having an AIO, so I don't have much to compare it to by way of comparison, but I will say for the price, aesthetics, functionality, and space-saving utility of not having to have a separate computer tower, this thing is an exceptional buy.Let's begin with the things I most love about it:1) The screen and display are gorgeous. The IPS display gives a wide gamut of rich, deep colors with great viewing angels. At 23 inches there isn't a tremendous amount of backlight bleed, and while the blacks aren't as deep as some alternatives to IPS, the vibrant color scheme more than makes up for it.2) The CPU is superb, and basically does everything you need it to do for most tasks. The thing comes with 6 cores, 2 performance for heavy duty single threaded tasks and 4 efficiency cores for multi-threaded ones. This is more than capable of handling most non-gaming tasks.3) The aesthetics and space-saving is totally wonderful. If the AIOs were priced super high, it wouldn't be worth it, because you could build significantly cheaper. But with the price of computer components so high, if you simply need a well-functioning desktop without all the bulk, get yourself an AIO!My biggest, major "complaint" is simply this: you're not going to do anything beyond very basic gaming on this AIO. The integrated graphics are fine for watching videos, browsing the web, playing browser-based games, etc. But for gaming you are missing a dedicated GPU, which makes this NOT ideal for gamers. Beyond that, there are only 8GB of ram in this Acer AIO, and as you can see, even idling, about 4GB of that ram is already used up just from Windows. There isn't a ton of excess RAM, and if I had one major complaint it would be that this should definitely come stocked with 16GB of ram.In short, while I have some minor complaints, I really think this is a great budget AIO with a beautiful display. For the space-conscious folks, you will love it!

reviewDescription: I bought this computer as the one I am using is old and clonky. I have cluttered it with all sorts of data such that it takes minutes to find what I want and I needed a dedicated computer I could run off-line for my work.So I bought this one.It arrived a day earlier than forecast. The packaging was awesome. I am surprised they did not wrap it in a couple of feather mattresses. They could have wrapped an elephant with all the bubble wrap they used. Everything was as promised and although there was no instructions the connections would be self evident to most. Included with the computer was a downright plea to contact them if anything was amiss.It took just a few minutes to put the beast together and the thing came to life when I switched on.But there was a problem,; one of the screen displays was wildly off center leaving a two inch black display void on the far left of the screen. I had received the unit that afternoon and by the time I discovered the problem it was slightly after 4 o'clock and their note said don't call after 4 as we won't answer.I was forced to wait another day. Early the next morning I called and a young lady answered the phone, took my account number and we got to work. We quickly narrowed the problem to the monitor and the menu buttons in the front. When pressed they announced that the menu was locked. It took less than ten minutes to discover how to unlock the device (hold the menu button for 30 seconds) amid much laughter and I was on my way. Great service and a satisfied customer!So far.

reviewedIn: Reviewed in the United States on December 2, 2022
reviewDescription: This review is for the Sinbun with 11th generation i-5 with 16GB RAM and 512 GB storage. My computer came with Windows 11 Pro but I soon discovered that it is not a fully functioning installation. The issue is that there are certain Windows apps that will not run/are not installed. One of the apps that doesn't open is the Windows Security app. This app is responsible for virus scans, fire wall, etc. When I open this app I get an error message "This app can't open". Other apps such as Windows Calculator give the same error. I have spent hours troubleshooting this but can not find a solution.UPDATE: After installing several windows updates that didn't solve the problem, a new update appeared called Win11 22H2. I installed this update and it corrected the issue. I am upgrading my review from 1 start to 4 stars. The computer works as expected, and the fan noise is no louder than my laptops fan. Also, the 500 GB ssd that comes with the pc is partitioned so the windows drive (which stores your windows documents, photos, music, etc.) can only hold 149 GB. The other partition is drive D: and it holds 326 GB.

reviewTitle: Finally a Mini PC that can actually replace a desktop computer
reviewedIn: Reviewed in the United States on August 30, 2022
reviewDescription: Overview - I have been building computers for over 20 years and am very tech savvy. I originally got this device to use as a dedicated system for a 1080p 32" touchscreen Alexa and Home automation system.  I wasnt really sure what to expect for speed and quality but it would be fine for that. When I received the computer, it was packaged very nicely and the quality was surprisingly good. After a quick glimpse at that manual, I just decided to plug it in and see what happens. The thing booted right up into Windows 11 Pro and Windows was already activated. Did an initial systems check to make sure RAM, HD, processor was what it was supposed to be. Then I found out that the i5-1135G7 is supposed to be a pretty good chip and actually comparable to my I59600k except with better built in GPU. So I did all the Windows updates and then ran several benchmarks on it to put it under stress. This mini pc breezed through everything. It got a little warm at times and the fan was noticeable, but not overbearing. Kind of like a laptop fan. This unit has really impressed me and its too good to use for my touchscreen system, so I am deciding on replacing one of my other desktops with this instead. All the ports worked without issue. It is a fast system for such a small form factor.TECHNICAL - comes with 16 gig of RAM expandable to 64 gig of SODIMM ddr4, The 512 NVME performed very well and you can easily switch it to a different drive. BTW nvme is a lot faster than any SSD Hard drive. To do any upgrades, you will need a jewelers screwdriver for the tiny 2 screws holding the cover on. I only took the system down to the "replaceable" parts and didnt take it all the way apart. I was unable to confirm if the Type C port is actually a Thunderbolt4 port or just a 10Gb/s USB port. The ad says 10Gig, but the user manual states Thunderbolt4. I have included screenshots of the dissassembly as well as the benchmarks. Keep in mind the benchmark percentages mean "better than xx% of all computers". When I dropped the resolution down to 1080p, there was a noticeable speed increase across the board. This is probably because the GPU is built on the CPU chip. Of course this unit doesnt have a $500 dedicated video card and there are faster processors, ram or hard drives, but for the price and expandability this is one heck of a fast system out of the box and it truly does compete in many ways with my custom desktop which costs a lot more. This unit even performs better than the numerous laptops I have tested and even some of the newer I7 laptops. I could not find who makes the MB nor could I find this vendors website anywhere. I am super impressed with this unit, the quality and the speed. I may even use this for on site purposes instead of my laptop because of the power and flexibility. The performance on this blows away my Surface Pro4 and it has all the latest Wifi Ax bluetooth 5.2. I connected to my network without any issue. Sorry for the long review, but there is a lot of details with any computer system

reviewTitle: Using it to type this review...
reviewedIn: Reviewed in the United States on September 5, 2022
reviewDescription: I have been using an HP laptop that I got years ago - at least 5, maybe as much as 7. I got a good one and it's still running great - even after updating to Windows 11. However, I was getting more and more errors and issues, so I decided to try this out. Super easy to set up - just turn it on and your off. I connected it to my wi-fi, logged into some of my accounts and let it "catch-up" and update the system and apps. I has zero issues but one - the Windows Store App wasn't working right (I could use it online through a browser, but not the native app). I got it to work and have been pleased. On my laptop, it took me 1 hour and 10 minutes copying all of my music to a USB key. Copying those same files took 4 minutes on this little PC. I think I'm most happy that the fan isn't loud and running non-stop. I got another mini-PC with an Intel Celeron processor that the fan runs all the time and is loud - it's annoying and distracting (I now run Linux  on it and it's much better). This mini doesn't have the fan issue. So far, I happy and I hope this one lasts as long as my HP. Overall, I am happy with it.

reviewTitle: The Mac mini has become a powerhouse
reviewedIn: Reviewed in the United States on March 9, 2023
reviewDescription: I bought the Mac Mini M2 chip with 10 cores, 512 GB of SS storage, two thunderbolt 4 ports, two USB-A ports, a 2.5 GHz ethernet port, an HDMI port and a headphone jack. The price was just too good to resist for the latest Mac Mini. Amazon had the best price at the time for the Mac Mini so I jumped at the chance. And I don‚Äôt regret it. I already had/have a 42 inch Apple display, so I didn‚Äôt have that expense. It took me a while to believe how fast this little unit is. I had three apps open at the same time: iPhoto, Apple Notes and Final Cut Pro, which is Apple‚Äôs proprietary nonlinear video editing app that is in the top three of all professional video editing programs. I was amazed at the speed with which the Mac Mini M2 chip could handle all three apps, because I was going between the three on a new project. Even if one has to purchase an external monitor to go with a Mac mini M2 chip I think it would be worth it. reviewDescription: I've been reluctant regarding the IOS infrastructure since the late 70's when I opted to partake in the x86 architecture in the form of the Radio Shack TRS-80. I still have my TRS-80 as a matter of fact,  although it has give up the 'ghost' for over 4 decades.Having weathered the storm of the Atari ST & multiple generational PCs for well over 50 years, in my senior years, I have decided to take the plunge into the MacOS Infrastructure.  So for I have been impressed with the Mac M2 Mini.  My major realization is that it is not your father's Windows PC.  The operating system is both graphical & keyboard shortcut enabled to a major degree.  The MacOS is not as simple or easy to use as I was lead to believe!  It requires a major relearning effort to master thie system!However, I must confess the set up & tweating of my new M2 Mac Mini has been a pleasant surprise.  I have been aided by Youtube in the form of multiple Mac Training & tips videos which have been a major resourcs in adapting to my new Mac Mini!  I will willlingly move deeper into the Mac as time goes by!

reviewTitle: This thing is a brilliant idea!
reviewedIn: Reviewed in the United States üá∫üá∏ on December 11, 2022
reviewDescription: I saw this and I knew I wanted one: I'm an older person who likes a big screen so I can increase text size for visibility. I use my computer for reading the news, email, social media, loads of writing, streaming, shopping, and researching everything. Chrome OS suits me: It is snappy and relatively safe from corruption.  I can access MS Office products on the web. I tend to store all my files in "the cloud," which means i can access everything from any device. I see people reviewing this product who did not understand they were buying a Chrome OS system. Because this has a unique design and an unusually large screen for Chrome OS, this All-in-One is over-priced. I ended up buying a version with less storage but at a greatly reduced price pre-holiday -- (I thought it was an error, nope, I got it) -- and returning this one, even though it was relatively well-priced at the time on Amazon. The screen is not anti-glare. I personally will not use the touch-screen function, although it might be very useful for education use, where a teacher, tutor, or parent is working with a student. I will use the portrait mode a lot for reading, writing, shopping, and social media. When used on the horizontal orientation, my unit is not 100% level and that annoys me because I see it -- not everyone would notice. Used on the horizontal, the screen is rather high, to allow it to swivel. (Now I really want a height-adjustible desk.)

reviewTitle: Before you buy this, research what printer you will use.
reviewedIn: Reviewed in the United States üá∫üá∏ on November 9, 2022
reviewDescription: This is a beautifully designed computer. Minimalist, small footprint, impressive screen that goes to tablet mode seamlessly, HOWEVER, finding a compatible printer could spoil the whole romance.  Seriously Google, make a compatible printer if this thing is going to be so finicky about connection!  Don't assume that particular brands are compatible, no, you will need to find make and specific model (check every number and letter) to find the perfect printing mate.  If you read reviews you will find that its a mixed bag of responses from works seamlessly, to hours to set up but rigged finally, to no, nada, nothing..just won't connect.  I have gone down some of those rabbit holes and settled with the recommendedBrother HL-L2350DW.  I set it up for wireless, everything looked good but nope, chromebase would not connect.  I used the usb connection and was relieved that it detected it and printed no problem.  I also tried wired connection with a samsung laser printer and nada. So figure it.  Otherwise the computer is a dream.  One other note, when I first set it up the wifi connection was hopeless but after a reboot all was well.  sigh...

reviewTitle: Incredibly quiet, very fast and easily expandable
reviewedIn: Reviewed in the United States on February 8, 2023
reviewDescription: I bought this to replace an ancient Dell Vostro 410 Core 2 Quad that came with Windows Vista but was running Windows 7 Ultimate. The first thing I noticed is how incredibly quiet this computer is compared to my previous one. It is almost silent. It is also much more compact, but still has plenty of room for expansion. I'm perfectly happy with the on-board video and I'm using it to drive a 30" 2560 x 1600 through a DisplayPort to DVI Dual Link adapter and a 20" monitor directly through an HDMI to DVI cable. Should I choose to use the computer for gaming someday, there's an available expansion slot for a modern video card, unused power connectors ready to go and a 300W power supply built-in. There's also a second expansion slot that's more than adequate for a peripheral card. The 16 GB of RAM it came with only uses one of the two memory slots, so I spent about $45 to add a Crucial 16 GB DIMM (part number CT16G4DFRA32A), bringing the total up to 32 GB. I'm not sure what a previous reviewer was talking about when they wrote that it uses proprietary memory, which couldn't be further from the truth. If I ever need more RAM, the system supports 64 GB. The internal 512 GB SSD is more than adequate for my current needs, but could be replaced easily. There's also a spot to mount a 3.5" internal hard drive which I'm using with a 2.5" adapter sled to hold an SSD I had in an old laptop. All the cabling I needed was inside and ready to go. The computer is also lightning fast. Did I mention how quiet and compact it is? I guess I still can't get over that. Having a DVD+RW drive is great for ripping CDs and being able to read and write other legacy media. Windows 11 Pro also seems to be quite stable and I like it a lot more than Windows 10 -- none of those annoying animated tiles on the Start menu that I was always too lazy to hide but never used. The shipping was lightning fast and I had the computer the day after I ordered it. It also came inside of an outer box, adding some extra protection during shipping. To me the only downside was the price -- I was always used to spending well under $750 for my desktop computers, and this was more than that, but it seemed a great value compared to the configurations I could purchase directly from Dell, so I still consider it a win.

reviewDescription: I've used this PC for five months.  It has fast start up and is overall quicker because of the SSD drive and 16 GB RAM. Windows 11 is working well but Microsoft "fixed" a few things that weren't broken to begin with.  Oh well.  This PC was a good purchase.

reviewTitle: DO NOT UPDATE THE BIOS TO 314! Otherwise, not a bad system for a discounted price.
reviewedIn: Reviewed in the United States on November 20, 2022
reviewDescription: This PC is solid and comes with all you need from the get go. Especially if you're on a budget and do not know how to build PCs. (Sale price at $700USD plus tax.) I had the unfortunate experience of having to troubleshoot this PC myself. It worked fine out of the box but after a while I experienced issues that came later on due to several issues. (Occurred on 11/20/2022)[Crashing Bios Update from Windows] Problem 1 (Update 11/28/2022)Bios Update 314 has since been removed from their website and optional windows update settings. So, your PC should work out of the box without issues, but I will keep this here in case anyone still ends up having it somehow.(Update 11/23/2022)The Bios Update in Windows Update Settings (This will show up as Asustek Firmware Update). DO NOT INSTALL THIS. It will crash your PC non-stop at random with the BSOD. This Bios Version is: 314.PC Model: G10CE- To fix this head over to the ROG ASUS Support website and find your PC model.- Click on Drivers & Utility and find Bios & Firmware Tab- Download Bios Version 309 For EZ Flash. Put in a USB for later in case of future problems.- Restart PC press F2 and go to Advanced settings. [Tools] ASUS EZ Flash 3 Utility.- Find your USB drive with the EZ Flash Bios file and install it.- If successful, your new Bios Version should be 309. (This can be seen at the top of the screen when you're in Advanced Settings ASUS EZ Flash.)This should fix your PC from crashing.PS. If your PC insists that it wants to update the bios again to 314.Type "Device Manager" in the search bar and find "System Firmware" and either disable or uninstall the update. I recommend uninstalling it.[CPU Heat & Fan Noise Revving] Problem 2The CPU runs hot at 70-85c at times even when you're not gaming. The PC will randomly rev the fan's speed to compensate for this to which I believe is not healthy for the CPU.- To fix this open Armoury Crate and turn on Manual Mode and set the fan speed to 50-100% instead of 0-100%. This alleviates the CPU temperature from 70-85 to 45-57 while keeping your fans from revving every so often.[Randomly Alt-Tabbing?] Problem 3 (Update 1/14/2022)I wouldn't know what to call this. My PC doesn't necessarily alt-tab, but whenever a folder is open my PC tends to switch to it at random times. Could be a few minutes or hours? It's completely random. I'm not sure what truly causes this.Unknown what causes this. Might be my external hard drive.Personal Fix: Do not have any folders open while gaming or doing any activities.[VR Headset/Oculus Rift S Black Screen/Static Sound/Beep Crashing] Problem 4 (Update 1/14/2022)I'm not sure how other VR Headsets will perform but the Rift S crashes for me after a while of playing at around 5-30 minutes for some reason. The USB ports built into the motherboard seem under-powered because my headset works fine on my other PC. (I have tried all USB ports and it still crashes.)- I fixed this by using a Sabrent USB 3.0 Hub with an A/C power plug and hooked it up to a USB 3.0 slot in the back (Blue USB Port). It stabilized the headset's connection to the PC and now works fine so far.PS. My headset audio was prickly like static without the Sabrent USB 3.0 Hub.Overall, this PC is decent for the price I got it for but I wouldn't recommend it at a higher price with some of the issues that had I had to deal with but you can make your own judgment on that. I would consider buying this PC as a cheap alternative to PC building. It's not as hard as it looks. I believe it will last you a good while until you've saved up enough money for things like:1. CPU Fans. (It runs hot while gaming and could be a little quieter.)- CPU runs hot at 75-85 while gaming (Playing Warhammer 40k: Darktide)- Tower only has 2 fans. One on the CPU and one in the back.2. Power Supply. (Comes with 500W Power Supply. Brand: ACBel P2B 500W.)3. HDD or SSD (You'll definitely need more space than 500GB for gaming or other needs.)- Windows 11 will take about 41GB of memory.- Total GB is 453. So, you'll probably only have 400GB to spare.4. New PC Tower (Tower is relatively small and compact.)Current PC Tower has no room for upgrades or add-ons. You cannot fit a full sized HDD. There is no mount. (Mine is lodged in a hole across from where the power supply is.)Personally, I'm looking into a HYTE Y60 or something similar with a lot of room for improvements and cooling.5. New Motherboard or USB Card or External USB Hub.Motherboard works fine as is, however, the USB ports deliver lackluster power output as far as I know. It cannot power my Oculus Rift S alone. It required a Sabrent 3.0 USB Hub to stabilize the connection.It works for basic needs like Keyboards, Mouses, USB Microphones like Blue Snowball ICE.However, for VR there may be some complications.My old PC which is an Acer Predator G6-710 with GTX 970 worked perfectly fine with VR. Audio never sounded prickly but the microphone tends to be robotic due to how Oculus designed the Rift S. Unfortunately, I do not know how other VR Headsets will fare with this PC, but it is something to consider.[Overall thoughts as a PC in general] 4 Stars: Would buy and troubleshoot again. :skull_emoji:In spite of the issues that this PC has made me troubleshoot. This PC is a 4 star in my book for the price I got it for, however, with the issues that people may or have experienced. I will have to keep this review at 3 stars due to the fact that people may still end up experiencing these issues somewhere down the line as they may end up buying this in the future.It is worth it as an entry level PC despite how bare bones it is. I would recommend considering buying upgrades to start building your own PC with its parts later down the line. It's not as hard as it looks.I bought this PC for a good price with the total being around 800 from Amazon as the seller. It was Black Friday though. So, you can make your own judgment on what price you'd rather have this for.PCs with the same specs have gone for around 1000-1400.Personally, I wouldn't pay more than 1000 for it considering some of the other options you can glance at which could have better cooling, specs, and room for upgradability.I wish that I could've recommended this PC at a 5 star rating with no faults or flaws. However, it does have several flaws which I have listed. Yet, in spite of what I had gone through to make it work. I would consider this PC to be a trooper. It was quite the adventure and challenge to troubleshoot the issues and in the end very rewarding to find the solutions to those faults.Maybe I have Stockholm Syndrome.Either way, I'm not a PC expert. Just a gamer who held a lot of determination and lived off of copium while trying to fix this PC. I did not want to return it at all considering the price was too good to pass up. I believe I will keep this PC for the spare parts in the future where I will end up building my own PC for the first time.I may have experienced problems, but I hope that as you read this you won't have to deal with the same issues. I hope this PC will serve you well should you choose to buy it. I will update this review to reflect further problems that may come around, but I think it'll be okay now.
variant: processor_description: Intel Core i5-11400Fmemory_size: 16 GBHard Disk Size: 512 GBGraphics Description: RTX 3060

reviewedIn: Reviewed in the United States on November 6, 2022
reviewDescription: this is the first pre-built computer I have purchased since 1994. Individual parts costs too much that is it not worth it anymore for what I do on a PC as I dont PC game anymore these days. My youngest son however plays Roblox and Fornite on PC. My current PC has a i7-4770 cpu!I purchased the G10CE with Intel i5-11400KF, Kingston 16 GB DDR4 3200, and Asus RTX 3060. $739 plus taxes, great price considering what the RTX 3060 goes for. Comes with Windows 11. The SSD is a 512 Gb NVMe WD SN-530 PCI 3.0. The motherboard is a micro-ATX Asus B560 chipset board. 500 W PSU. Didnt check the brand. The case is fairly small for a tower case. It is not greatly ventilated at all. Does have a led RGB strip inside at the top of the case. Has 2 USB 3 ports on the top of the case.The performance of the computer is fine so far. Setup was a breeze. Updated windows, all drivers and software plus the bios of the motherboard. PC boots up in less than 15 secs. The biggest thing that holds this PC back is the motherboard. It is really limited. You cant adjust much of anything in the bios. It has 1 included 92 mm case fan and the cpu fan is also a 92 mm fan. They are SUPER noisy and you cannot adjust the speed of the fans. The case fan header is only 3 pin so you cannot replace it with a 4-pin PWN fan to make it quieter, but you can get another CPU cooler with a bigger 4-pin PWN fan to replace that fan. I found a low profile Cooler Master heatsink and fan unit with a 120 mm PWN fan for $23 on Amazon that should do the trick.Biggest question is can you add another NVMe PCI 3.0 SSD in the other M.2 slot for additional storage space and will the motherboard actually detect it being a B560 chipset. If not, there is some room at the bottom of the case where you can mount a 2.5 inch SSD but there is no way of getting a 3.5 inch HDD to fit in this case.This is great computer for someone on a budget that wants to game at 1080p. You should be able to run max settings on most modern games with the RTX 3060. The other hardware in this PC should not hold you backHowever i am returning it as the aftermarket cpu cooler did not help make it any quieter and i cannot tolerate the fan noise.

reviewTitle: Fairly decent computer that could be awesome with a bit of tweaking
reviewedIn: Reviewed in the United States on December 11, 2022
reviewDescription: First off, I bought this thing for $850. It was a great deal, but honestly anything under a grand and its worth the money.This thing does everything its supposed to do, but it runs hot. I don't use the glass panel, and yet my CPU regularly ran around 80 degrees C. There is a way around this that doesn't invalidate the warranty, fortunately. The Armory Crate software allows you to manually set the fan speed. Crank it to 50% minimum, and your CPU will be chilling at 60-70 even while gaming. Maybe I'm burning out my fan doing this, but I'd rather have to buy a new heat sink than a new CPU.There are probably better solutions than to mess with your fan, but ripping the front panel off would invalidate the warranty. Honestly, it kind of infuriates me that the covered up a possible vent and place to put a second fan so they could put RGBs. I like the cool factor as much as anyone else, but not at the expense of performance.

reviewedIn: Reviewed in the United States on November 10, 2022
reviewDescription: Ok, so, I want to start off this review by saying it‚Äôs been 2 months since I got this PC, and I am pretty happy with it. It runs all games I play on high FPS on max settings. Valorant >200, Overwatch >220, World of Warcraft >100 (with ray tracing). Perhaps the only downside is a single exhaust fan, which, if you put the glass side panel, will not be enough to cool down your system. It runs at 70-80 degrees Celsius on both GPU and CPU. The metal panel actually has some holes in it, so the fresh air can flow in and significantly reduce the temps. It does get a bit noisy after a while, but I honestly don‚Äôt really hear anything if I wear my headphones. So, all in all, good mid range PC, a little hot for my taste, and a bit noisy, but powerful enough if you play the games I mentioned. I should also mention that I got it while the price was $1099, so that‚Äôs another plus.

reviewTitle: How to make work for music.
reviewedIn: Reviewed in the United States on April 6, 2022
reviewDescription: It's a good machine, but be prepared of a few things. Nothing necessarily bad, but you need to know. 500W power is barely enough to keep it functioning. I bought a 750W for about $60 and swapped it.Next, the cooler for the CPU is a bare-bones cheap unit Figure $45 and swap it out as well.This is normal for most manufacturers, folks. They know you're buying based on the stats you want, and keep the little stuff as cheap as possible.For music, in my case Ableton 11 Suite running in a pro studio, there were issues with the Intel Turbo setting. It's an on/off deal you manage from Bios. Just kill it if you're experiencing power shut-downs. This is not necessarily unique to this build. Intel just points their fingers at everyone but themselves, like out-dated drivers and so forth. My build had all new drivers and still shut down about once a day until I traced it to Intel Turbo. So, I removed a star from my rating because reliability is king in music production, and this computer, even with updated power and cooling, still can't run continuously under a moderate load.Of course, just toggle off that buggy Intel Turbo, and you're all set. I wish i could use it, but the world of circular finger-pointing and denial isn't worth my time to deal with.As it stands, though it's a monster computer, even without the Turbo working reliably.I run 20+ tracks with virtual instruments and plugins at 30% CPU use, and temps under 60 degrees Celsius, max.There's a lot more room this computer can offer me, in terms of tracks and plugins. More than I'll ever need for the foreseeable future.So, go ahead and buy it, but know to kill that Turbo in Bios, and be prepared to upgrade the cooler, and the power as well, possibly.

reviewTitle: An inexpensive computer with 8GB of memory and a 128 GB SSD that runs Windows 11
reviewedIn: Reviewed in the United States on March 1, 2022
reviewDescription: I have recently found out that many of my computers will not run Windows 11.  Therefore I need to upgrade a number of computers.  This small computer is a reasonable option for most of the application that I use. (word processing and web browsing).  Contrary to what others have said, it came with Windows 11 Pro preinstalled.  I did not need a license code to register it with Microsoft.  I was able to create an offline account.  It took a few downloads, but it is now upgraded to the latest version of Windows 11.For comparison, I recently purchased a mini-tower from a major computer manufacture based in Texas with an i5-10400 processor that costed 2 1/2 times more than the Kamrui.  But for most of tasks I do, there is not a large noticeable difference.  I was doubtful  about the Celeron J4125 processor, but it has sufficient power for word processing and web browsing.  I downloaded a common set of benchmark tests and they confirmed that the CPU performance is significantly  lower that the i5 system.But there are many things I like about this system.  It does have a fan and I do not find it any noisier than other computer systems.  I has 3 USB3.0 ports and I found that at least one of them is powered even when the computer is off, so I can use it for charging my phone.  I used the USB port to create an backup image to a USB 3.0 drive and the write speed was around 600 to 700 MB/sec, which is fine.One pleasant surprise was the performance of the wireless adapter.  I have the computer located close to my 5G wireless router and using Fast.com, the wireless download speed was 300 MB/sec.  That is the same speed I measure when using the 1 GB wired Ethernet adapter.It has two HDMI display ports and one VGA port.  I am using the VGA port with a KVM (Keyboard-Video-Mouse) switch and it works fine.  It also has an internal bay that can hold a 2.5 inch SSD or hard drive.  At some point I will install an old 2.5 inch hard drive and use it to store backup images.I will admit that I was skeptical that I could buy a computer that was adequate to run Windows 11 for around $200 (there was a discount available when I bought it).  But so far it has exceeded my expectations.  I will probably be buying more of these in the future.

reviewTitle: Great desktop replacement computer for business..
reviewedIn: Reviewed in the United States on August 22, 2022
reviewDescription: Replaced a Optoplex 790 pc with the GK3 version.. I can take it on the road(RV) for business and vacation without issues.. great Bluetooth. HDMI, and USB 2/3 connections... only lacking an audio output(works thru HDMI fine)...  did not want Win11, so contacted the tech support folks and the sent a link to reload Win10Pro(64bit).. after setting up a USB drive, the reinstall went fast and the results excellent... the primary SSD is only 128GB, so installed a 1TB SSD and moved all the folders to it... added an additional USB Hub for multiple printers, camera, and dvd burner without issues... the 8GB of RAM allows all the functionality of W10P and programs like QuickBooks to operate without issues...  I would recommend this for a full replacement computer...

reviewedIn: Reviewed in the United States on June 14, 2022
reviewDescription: KAMRUI-Mini GK3, RAM 8GB - ROM 128GBDual Boot - Win X11 and Ubuntu 20.04.4LTSWin X11 install no issues. Ran update after initial boot to monitor update process, updates required 2 restarts. (took forever) Created a USB RECOVERY Disk (bootable). In Windows ran Disk Manager and shrunk 128GB to 50%, left other 50% Unallocated.Entered BIOS (esc or delete) and set USB to boot first. Save and ExitInstalled Ubuntu 20.04.4LTS along side of Windows.Entered BIOS (esc or delete), BOOT / UEFI Harddisk Drive BBS / set Ubuntu boot manager to position 1. Save and ExitNow in Ubuntu, WiFi driver not installed. Used Bluetooth cell connection.In Terminal:# sudo apt-get update# sudo apt-get install rtl8821ce-dkmsRan updates with WiFi.Very Happy Now, great little PC!!!

reviewedIn: Reviewed in the United States üá∫üá∏ on April 17, 2023
reviewDescription: Amazon advertises this machine with four memory slots - the mother board only has two.Other than that, this is a great machine for beginning to mid level gamers. It has enough power and video capability for every game that I currently play.As this was a gift, I upgraded the RAM to 16Gig and tested it before I presented to my daughter.To date, she has been very happy with this machine.

reviewedIn: Reviewed in the United States üá∫üá∏ on May 3, 2023
reviewDescription: Works great! No issues whatsoever and looks nice

reviewedIn: Reviewed in the United States üá∫üá∏ on January 23, 2023
reviewDescription: Pretty decent value, I think, for the price range. I use it for Steam gaming and CG art. Looks fairly cool with red LEDs on the inside. Haven't upgraded anything except adding a SATA and nvme SSD just to hold Steam games. Might add RAM in the future, but has enough for most of my uses.Biggest complaint is the proprietary power supply unit (PSU). Hard to say how reliable it is and no aftermarket options last I checked. The cables may look normal, but the wiring inside is not. It also used to make a ticking sound, but seems to have gone away after a few months. I recommend at least using a surge protector and backing up your files regularly.

reviewedIn: Reviewed in the United States üá∫üá∏ on January 14, 2023
reviewDescription: Editing my review because it turns out the issue I was having also happened after I returned the Nitro and bought a different computer.I was getting black screens a lot during my games and thought it was an issue with the GPU on the Nitro. It turns out the issue was because my monitor is rated for 200 mhz, and my FPS cap was set too high for my monitor. The GPU was more than sufficient, and was actually outperforming my monitor, which was why the issue was occurring.The Nitro should be able to handle most games. I never got to really experience it because of my own fault, but seems like it should do good and at a good price point.

reviewedIn: Reviewed in the United States üá∫üá∏ on November 8, 2022
reviewDescription: This was surprisingly easy to carry into another room and set up, and to a person that originally only had a puny 2 Gb on her graphics card and was not able to play any game that came out after 2020, now the graphics are astonishingly better. Do yourself a favor, though, and order a HDMI to VGA converter with this if you are like me and do not have the latest and greatest monitor to plug in - mine is widescreen, but is VGA and I could not use the new graphic card until I had the right cable. It also does not have a DVD or CD-rom, so if you need one you have to order that, too. Once you get over the audacity of such a thing now not being included in a computer, that is. Laptops have long been doing that, and floppy disk drives I get, but in a desktop tower with lots of room?!

reviewTitle: An awesome pc recommend you buy it
reviewedIn: Reviewed in the United States üá∫üá∏ on March 18, 2023
reviewDescription: It perfect works well look awesome I think the only down side is it does not have a lot of storage but you can just order that other than that it‚Äôs awesome.

reviewedIn: Reviewed in the United States üá∫üá∏ on February 24, 2023
reviewDescription: Proprietary board limits the power supplies you can use

reviewedIn: Reviewed in the United States üá∫üá∏ on January 5, 2023
reviewDescription: I had initially bought this as a gift for my wife as she was using my 7-year-old pc thinking in the future id drop in a hard drive or another nvme drive and boy was I wrong , for starters the very first thing i was greeted with was and repair loop (yes first time boot up ) already annoyed christmas morning by this i decided to troubleshoot the issue which i eventually got it up and running so from there i wanted to see just how much space there would be to put in another drive ( this day and age 500gb really isn't much ) and kind of surprised it has 2 sata ports on the motherboard yet no way to power them at all you would need to upgrade the power supply which i would have intended to do in the future however, after a windows 11 update it went back into a repair loop which at that point for such a low end pc didn't feel it was worth the effort and just returned it . Nice compact design but for 8 gb of ram , a meh gpu a decent cpu and barely enough space to add a few games it wasn't worth the headache

reviewTitle: Worked for 2 weeks reboots on it's own then long beep, then dead.  No power at all
reviewedIn: Reviewed in the United States üá∫üá∏ on April 6, 2023
reviewDescription: I'm still working with the seller to try to fix the situation.  The computer showed up, I removed all the bloat (programs I'll never participate in).  I do video editing and sound design so just needed something for semi-heavy rendering with Vegas Pro 20 & Studio One 6 Recording software.  2 weeks in, everything happened in 1 day.  Rebooted on it's own.  No big deal right?  Then a couple hours later during light work load (no gaming, I'm not a gamer) long beep that wouldn't stop.  Turned off with the power button.  Waited maybe 10 minutes.  Pushed the power button; nothing, no power.  Been through all the troubleshooting (most of which I couldn't do because no power) but I figured they knew something I didn't.  It is currently a paperweight.  I will proably come back and update this later but if someone asked me today, I'd say DO NOT buy this computer.  I've heard about nothing but problems, even possession after doing more research on the internet.  I guess Acer doesn't care about their customers.  I like Lenova.  I've had 3 in the past 10 years and have had nothing but good experiences.  My T430 Laptop has out lasted everything.  I'm on it now.  Stay tuned for more later.**Update, looks like it's going for warranty work.  It's been well over a month to resolve so, for me, I had to buy another computer because I cannot go that long.  I will still get this back and will use it for something else I guess.  Don't know if this is just bad luck or what but I've spent $1600 on computers in the past 40 days.  If you can afford it, go for it.

reviewedIn: Reviewed in the United States on April 23, 2020
reviewDescription: I bought this with the assumption that it was a tower computer as indicated by the images.  My computer desk setup requires a tower, however, this is a computer designed for a horizontal installation.  There are no feet on the side of the case to provide support and the faceplate has a curve to it, so there is a gap and the face supports the weight of the computer rather than the case.  Additionally, one of the feet was missing for the horizontal install, so it would not be stable if installed that way.  I never even powered it up so I cannot attest to how it functions, but it was not what I needed for my purposes.They did take it back for a return with no issues.

reviewedIn: Reviewed in the United States on December 15, 2022
reviewDescription: Contrary to the description, this Chromebase has NO anti glare film or screen. It's extremely reflective. Also, looking to upgrade the ram. I wished 8gb of memory would be the minimum for 2022 and beyond. But it's an OK product "for the money"

reviewedIn: Reviewed in the United States on July 22, 2022
reviewDescription: I'm a big ChromeOS fan since the start. I've had numerous Chromebook's, ChromeBox's and ChromeBase's.I replaced my wife's 22" Chromebase with this and was surprised at the screen size. I've had 22" screens before and 21.5 has never looked so small. I haven't measured the screen, but it seems more like a 19" screen to me.The rotation option is pretty neat and the sound is good.Happy with the product, however, and would definitely recommend ChromeOS in any form factor. It reduces my immediate and extended family tech support work significantly!

reviewedIn: Reviewed in the United States on January 28, 2023

The os itself is so smooth and so simple absolutely perfect for any and every home kitchen living room whatever. I promise. I bought 3 more.

reviewedIn: Reviewed in the United States on December 13, 2022
reviewDescription: The computer is a great value and easy to use. I'm enjoying it!

reviewTitle: Decent device but a little sluggish
reviewedIn: Reviewed in the United States on January 27, 2022
reviewDescription: The reason for a 3 star review is two-fold. While the device is beautiful from a design perspective, the rotating screen is better in theory than practice. When rotated in the horizontal (normal) position, the screen actually settles at a slight angle. I'd judge it to be 5 degrees off center. Not the end of the world but a noticable annoyance. Second, the system is a little sluggish. It could simply be that I'm used to a more powerful, pro-level work computer. But even without taxing the system, you can notice a 1 second plus delay in opening new web apps, etc. I'd recommend this as a nice casual use device. But if you plan to use it for school or work, probably worth upgrading to a slightly more powerful device.

reviewedIn: Reviewed in the United States on October 2, 2022
reviewDescription: I can't access my favorite online MPG games. This was the entire reason I bought a new PC. What a waste.

reviewedIn: Reviewed in the United States on August 18, 2022
reviewDescription: I TRANSITIONED FROM AN HP ALL-IN-ONE, WINDOWS O/S TO THE HP CHROME O/S.  FASTER, MORE EFFECTIVE AND PURCHASED AT AN AFFORDABLE PRICE.  A GREAT DEAL FASTER AND MUCH LESS STRAIN ON THIS SUPER SENIOR CITIZEN.

reviewedIn: Reviewed in the United States on February 9, 2022
reviewDescription: I'm a basic computer user.  I use it for emails, watching YouTube videos and writing occasional documents/spreadsheets.
